description: Cisco ASA Express Security refers to the firewall product line that comes from Cisco. This course prepares the viewers for the Cisco ASA Express Security exam (500-260), which covers basic firewall configuration as well as the new features found in Cisco FirePOWER (formerly FireSIGHT) and is commonly required for Cisco Channel Partners that are selling and promoting Cisco Adaptive Security Appliances (ASA). One should attain the knowledge to at least be able to take an ASA out of the box, configure it to a network, get it filtering traffic and successfully get FirePOWER enabled and running. The knowledge one can attain in the CCENT and CCNA can serve as a great foundation base when learning about Cisco ASA.
name: Cisco ASA Express Security
subtitle: Next Generation Firewall

episodes.description: This course prepares the viewers for the Cisco ASA Express Security exam (500-260). The exam covers basic firewall configuration as well as the new features found in Cisco FirePOWER (formerly FireSIGHT). This exam is commonly required for Cisco Channel Partners that are selling and promoting Cisco Adaptive Security Appliances (ASA).
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

In this video,

00:08:22.943 --> 00:08:26.872

episodes.description: In this episode Todd and Don introduce the viewers to the Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance product line. Afterwards, Todd demonstrates the initial configuration of an ASA to get it up and running.
episodes.title: Introduction to ASA

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd and Don walk through the initial steps to configure an ASA for production deployment. Todd starts by manually performing the basic configuration from the first episode. He then demonstrates the firewall actively blocking traffic.

So then, logging on and
now that sees I'm logging, and

So let me go over here and log in here.

00:23:58.160 --> 00:23:59.623
Let's see if I can see anything.

515
00:23:59.623 --> 00:24:01.143
This is my Kali Linux.

516
00:24:01.143 --> 00:24:04.198
And so now I'm gonna attack that

the default gateway is already

when it sends the attack

00:24:09.510 --> 00:24:10.780

Yeah, we really haven't

we don't really need much to

So let's see if it did anything.

523
00:24:21.110 --> 00:24:22.280
Not yet.
Did I get it.

>> Yeah, at this point we haven't
configured any firewall rules, so

00:24:26.240 --> 00:24:29.230
we're strictly relying upon

00:24:29.230 --> 00:24:31.070
Right?
The fact that your external host,

your Kali Linux host is out there

00:24:38.980 --> 00:24:42.290

number, it should be blocked by default,

530
00:24:42.290 --> 00:24:44.990
even if you haven't configured

531
00:24:44.990 --> 00:24:47.890
But then that inside host is on a 100,
they should be able to get

00:24:47.890 --> 00:24:50.910
out to the Internet,
which is a zero, and browse out and

533
00:24:50.910 --> 00:24:54.240
access whatever it is they want to
access because it's a higher number.

534
00:24:54.240 --> 00:24:56.670
And that is all without
configuring firewall rules.

00:24:56.670 --> 00:25:00.020
>> Absolutely, so
I was able to go out to the Kali Linux and

00:25:00.020 --> 00:25:01.660
we're gonna do some attacks from it.

But the one thing that you can do by

I can't ping through it and

But by default, I can't ping through it,
but I can ping the interfaces.

00:25:18.540 --> 00:25:19.930
So let's talk about that for one second.

00:25:19.930 --> 00:25:22.530
So, I basically there's outside
of my Kali Linux and like okay,

I'm sending this attack,
nothing's happening.

544
00:25:24.340 --> 00:25:25.870
Let me ping it, make sure I'm alive.

545
00:25:25.870 --> 00:25:28.720
And we can see,
this is my connection table, right.

546
00:25:28.720 --> 00:25:31.280
So this is actually what's happening.

547
00:25:31.280 --> 00:25:35.582
So, an objective for your exam here is
when a packet comes in, that packet is

that already before it

00:25:42.530 --> 00:25:44.691
All right so that's an exam objective.

Connection table is checked first.

And we can see this with the show

00:25:51.390 --> 00:25:53.420
Show all local hosts,
yeah that's my connection table.

554
00:25:53.420 --> 00:25:56.430
There's really no connection because
here's what happens as soon as

00:25:56.430 --> 00:25:58.670
I was to ping through and

00:25:58.670 --> 00:26:02.900
this is actually just logging, telling

00:26:02.900 --> 00:26:05.200
But if I was to ping through it,

558
00:26:05.200 --> 00:26:07.509
To really see this we're going to
have to do something like telnet or

00:26:07.509 --> 00:26:08.245
something with TCP.

560
00:26:08.245 --> 00:26:09.031
>> Something with TCP.

00:26:09.031 --> 00:26:12.323
Yeah, you get a hand shake, you build
that connection, and you hold it open for

00:26:12.323 --> 00:26:13.070
a period of time.

00:26:13.070 --> 00:26:16.270
i see MP every packet is its

00:26:16.270 --> 00:26:17.350
So you don't see much.

00:26:17.350 --> 00:26:18.140
>> Absolutely.

566
00:26:18.140 --> 00:26:22.430
Now, so
I want to be able to ping from my insides,

00:26:22.430 --> 00:26:25.970
so if I'm on my inside host here,
let's go ahead and take a look.

00:26:25.970 --> 00:26:27.140
So here, I'm at the ASA.

00:26:27.140 --> 00:26:29.580
I ping the interface
from the outside host.

00:26:29.580 --> 00:26:31.780
Let's go ahead and

This is my ASA inside interface here.

Now, remember we said inside and outside,

00:26:39.836 --> 00:26:40.783
12, 250.

00:26:40.783 --> 00:26:41.572
That's the outside host.

00:26:41.572 --> 00:26:44.789
In other words, ping through and always
would allow a response back if I'm going

00:26:44.789 --> 00:26:46.930
from a high interface to
a low interface MAC, right?

00:26:46.930 --> 00:26:48.420
But we're gonna see that's not allowed.

00:26:48.420 --> 00:26:49.810
And let's go ahead and take a look why.

579
00:26:49.810 --> 00:26:52.500
All right, so here I am here.

580
00:26:52.500 --> 00:26:55.030
Let's tear down, so
let's take this apart, right?

581
00:26:55.030 --> 00:26:59.520
So notice I'm creating the connection and

583
00:27:03.150 --> 00:27:06.200
When that comes back it is gonna

584
00:27:06.200 --> 00:27:06.950
It never keeps it.

585
00:27:06.950 --> 00:27:09.580
It doesn't allow to keep
that session open so

00:27:09.580 --> 00:27:12.595
someone can see, I don't know do a smurf
attack or ping or something like that.

587
00:27:12.595 --> 00:27:14.160
That's what the reality is.

588
00:27:14.160 --> 00:27:17.790
So we can see here that, okay,
so tear down ICMP connection, so

589
00:27:17.790 --> 00:27:21.180
I've sent it out there,
ping 10 11 11 here.

590
00:27:21.180 --> 00:27:23.860
Okay, so it says the local
host was then been torn down.

591
00:27:23.860 --> 00:27:25.720
This was me pinging the inside host.

592
00:27:25.720 --> 00:27:28.700
Now, I'm building one that says,
hey, I want to go to 10.11.12.250.

593
00:27:28.700 --> 00:27:33.193
It says, outbound ICMP connection for
fast using the address,

594
00:27:33.193 --> 00:27:37.810
10.11.12.250 going to 10.11.11.11.

595
00:27:37.810 --> 00:27:44.204
We're gonna deny the source going
to the outside to 10.11.12.250.

596
00:27:44.204 --> 00:27:48.600
Coming from 10.11.11.11,
now this is type zero code zero,

597
00:27:48.600 --> 00:27:52.460
those are ICMP codes, let's go ahead and
we just have a few more, we have enough

598
00:27:52.460 --> 00:27:56.110
time left on this episode, let's go and
look at ICMP codes for a second.

599
00:27:56.110 --> 00:28:00.660
So ICMP error codes, how does that sound?

600
00:28:00.660 --> 00:28:01.560
Error codes.

601
00:28:03.190 --> 00:28:06.532
Should come up with something here, and
you can see, I've been there before.

602
00:28:06.532 --> 00:28:08.250
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And we got zero.

603
00:28:08.250 --> 00:28:09.250
It's an echo reply.

604
00:28:09.250 --> 00:28:12.446
So basically in here, it's an echo reply.

605
00:28:12.446 --> 00:28:13.864
We're denying it.

606
00:28:13.864 --> 00:28:17.328
So, when I allow,
when we come back in the next episode,

00:28:17.328 --> 00:28:21.890
we're gonna go ahead and fix this,

We did say that the higher Level of

609
00:28:25.450 --> 00:28:28.010
But I'm not able to ping right now, and

the fact is that if I did something
else like telnet, it would work.

611
00:28:32.580 --> 00:28:35.460
So why is it that ping's not working?

612
00:28:35.460 --> 00:28:38.500
>> And it goes back to what I mentioned
earlier about how with ping, every single

613
00:28:38.500 --> 00:28:43.690
packet's its own session and Cisco handles
it differently and unless we're inspecting

614
00:28:43.690 --> 00:28:47.240
that, unless the firewall's aware of
what that is, it's not going to work.

615
00:28:47.240 --> 00:28:50.860
>> And really we need to inspect it
because it's going out one protocol,

616
00:28:50.860 --> 00:28:52.030
coming back another.

617
00:28:52.030 --> 00:28:54.656
That really freak us out the ASA
is never going to let something,

618
00:28:54.656 --> 00:28:56.613
I don't know if it freaks out,
but I freak out.

619
00:28:56.613 --> 00:28:59.633
>> [LAUGH]
>> I don't know about ASA but

00:28:59.633 --> 00:29:02.470
that's my norm So anyways,
keep an eye on this.

621
00:29:02.470 --> 00:29:05.990
We're coming back to these error codes

00:29:05.990 --> 00:29:06.790

623
00:29:06.790 --> 00:29:12.100
But in this case here we're not allowing

00:29:12.100 --> 00:29:14.980
So what we're gonna do is we're gonna

we've been long enough, and

And because we're in such a small network

configure NAD and

how different they than the ASAs and

00:29:29.870 --> 00:29:32.010
Those are in upcoming episodes,

But in the next one here what we're
gonna do is we're gonna fix this,

we're going to inspect ICMP and then we're

634
00:29:41.380 --> 00:29:45.340
Right, and what we're going to learn from

00:29:45.340 --> 00:29:49.610
specific applications for businesses as
that have customized applications and

00:29:49.610 --> 00:29:52.020
that's real big on this on this objective.

00:29:52.020 --> 00:29:54.930
>> Yeah, and that's gonna be a key piece
of deploying an ASA in new environment

00:29:54.930 --> 00:29:58.520
because only you know what needs to
be allowed through your firewall.

639
00:29:58.520 --> 00:30:02.270
The default is inside host allowed,
outside host allowed, or not allowed in.

640
00:30:02.270 --> 00:30:03.750
>> Yeah, yeah yeah.
>> Almost screwed that up.

641
00:30:03.750 --> 00:30:05.390
But then, you'll have to poke holes for

642
00:30:05.390 --> 00:30:08.900
each of the various protocols and
ICMP may or may not be one of them.

643
00:30:08.900 --> 00:30:11.430
Alight well Tom, that's a pretty good
spot for us to wrap this one up.

644
00:30:11.430 --> 00:30:14.190
Like you mentioned, we definitely
have more coming up because we

646
00:30:15.555 --> 00:30:16.620
>> [LAUGHING]
>> So we are going to do that next.

647
00:30:16.620 --> 00:30:20.460
So stay tuned for our next episode but
until then thank you guys for watching.

648
00:30:20.460 --> 00:30:23.020
Signing off for ITPro.tv, I'm Don Pisette.

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd and Don continue with the initial ASA configuration. Todd demonstrates the final steps of an initial configuration and then explains how to configure protocol inspection to allow Ping and Traceroute to function.
episodes.title: Initial Configuration Part 2

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2

All right, good morning,
good afternoon, good evening, and

00:00:16.941 --> 00:00:18.770
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

5

Back again with another episode

6

And in this episode we're gonna continue

7

In our last episode we left you with

configured, but we weren't able to ping
from the inside out because we were

00:00:33.790 --> 00:00:35.090

10
00:00:35.090 --> 00:00:37.940
So we're going to pick right back up
where we left off in Part One and

11
00:00:37.940 --> 00:00:40.160
get that fixed and
allow that traffic to pass through.

12
00:00:40.160 --> 00:00:43.490
And here to help, as always, we've got Mr.
Todd Lammle here in the studio with us.

13
00:00:43.490 --> 00:00:45.940
And Todd, where are we going from here?

14
00:00:45.940 --> 00:00:48.643
>> Well, that's a good question,
because we're going to go ahead and

15
00:00:48.643 --> 00:00:51.533
take look at the routing table and

00:00:51.533 --> 00:00:53.116
make sure we can ping both our hosts, and

00:00:53.116 --> 00:00:55.802
the hosts can both ping our
interfaces by default that's enabled.

18
00:00:55.802 --> 00:00:59.979
I'm going to show you how to disable that
because when we put your ASA in you want

19
00:00:59.979 --> 00:01:00.940
to ping it right?

20
00:01:00.940 --> 00:01:03.330
Test connectivity make sure
everything is going fine.

21
00:01:03.330 --> 00:01:06.570
And then you can go ahead and turn that

00:01:06.570 --> 00:01:08.850
But certainly turn off the outside one.

23
00:01:08.850 --> 00:01:13.810
So then the other thing we were doing is,
I was trying to just ping through using

24
00:01:13.810 --> 00:01:16.900
it as an application right and
it was a really great example.

25
00:01:16.900 --> 00:01:20.320
Cuz we discussed, it goes out UDP and
comes back ICP error messages.

26
00:01:20.320 --> 00:01:22.050
So the fact is, because it does that,

27
00:01:22.050 --> 00:01:24.320
it doesn't work by default
unless we inspect it.

28
00:01:24.320 --> 00:01:27.580
So that's why, if we take a look at what
we're gonna inspect, and we will get into

29
00:01:27.580 --> 00:01:31.140
the inspection engine in a little
bit more detail in another episode.

30
00:01:31.140 --> 00:01:35.810
But let's just go ahead and fix the issue
that we have and make it work, okay?

31
00:01:35.810 --> 00:01:38.842
And then take a look at
the connection table.

32
00:01:38.842 --> 00:01:40.870
All right so let's come down here and

33
00:01:40.870 --> 00:01:43.850
understand that if we do
a show run policy map.

34
00:01:43.850 --> 00:01:45.720
I want to show you this though.

35
00:01:45.720 --> 00:01:49.680
And we take a look at this and
if we did a run all,

36
00:01:49.680 --> 00:01:53.480
like a show run all policy map,
we'd see an enormous amount.

37
00:01:53.480 --> 00:01:56.250
And we're going to take a look at
what the really inspection is and

38
00:01:56.250 --> 00:01:58.890
what's going on in those
inspection engines, so we can see.

39
00:01:58.890 --> 00:02:02.530
You know first off there is three things
we need to pay attention to here,

40
00:02:02.530 --> 00:02:05.190
when we are inspecting traffic.

41
00:02:05.190 --> 00:02:07.519
The first thing is you create a class,
right.

42
00:02:07.519 --> 00:02:13.090
You created this class map so basically
this default, I usually use a default but

43
00:02:13.090 --> 00:02:16.690
you're going to see when we get to the
source fire that I created another class.

44
00:02:16.690 --> 00:02:18.770
Now class tells us what to inspect.

45
00:02:19.870 --> 00:02:24.200
Then we put that into
a container called a policy map.

46
00:02:24.200 --> 00:02:29.390
So this policy map holds classes and
these classes tell us what to inspect,

47
00:02:29.390 --> 00:02:31.870
and I can have multiple
different classes under there.

48
00:02:31.870 --> 00:02:35.210
Then the policy, the reason we put it all
in a policy map, cause then we can take

49
00:02:35.210 --> 00:02:38.770
all these different parameters and
put them on an interface and

50
00:02:38.770 --> 00:02:41.260
I can't see it with this command,
but if I did a show run.

51
00:02:42.350 --> 00:02:43.810
And came down to the bottom.

52
00:02:43.810 --> 00:02:45.020
I'll just go all the way down.

53
00:02:45.020 --> 00:02:47.330
It's almost the last thing,
always, in your config.

54
00:02:47.330 --> 00:02:48.700
And we're gonna see the service policy.

55
00:02:48.700 --> 00:02:52.560
This is really part three
of the inspection engine.

56
00:02:52.560 --> 00:02:55.280
So we have our policy map, and
in there we have our classes,

57
00:02:55.280 --> 00:02:56.290
which tell us what to inspect.

58
00:02:56.290 --> 00:02:57.850
And then we're gonna take all that,

59
00:02:57.850 --> 00:03:01.210
and put this on the interfaces
with the service policy.

60
00:03:01.210 --> 00:03:03.560
In this case here,
we're saying use the global policy.

61
00:03:03.560 --> 00:03:06.510
And globally put that on all interfaces.

62
00:03:06.510 --> 00:03:09.110
And I like to use the global policy a lot.

63
00:03:09.110 --> 00:03:11.360
It makes it simple, it's easy to see, but

64
00:03:11.360 --> 00:03:13.030
there's a lot of reasons why we
would create a different one.

65
00:03:13.030 --> 00:03:17.290
Secondly, I can have many different
policies on the same interfaces, and

66
00:03:17.290 --> 00:03:20.850
this becomes important when we have a lot
of applications that we want to inspect.

67
00:03:20.850 --> 00:03:25.560
But in this case here, so I'm in
the ASA and I'm gonna ping 10 11 11 11,

68
00:03:25.560 --> 00:03:26.760
that's my inside host.

69
00:03:26.760 --> 00:03:29.810
And then you can see
the connection table and

70
00:03:29.810 --> 00:03:33.420
basically because I have that login I'm
gonna keep that on for a little bit.

71
00:03:33.420 --> 00:03:37.470
But you can see that this actually worked,
built outbound ICMP connection.

72
00:03:37.470 --> 00:03:40.090
Remember, this is a directly
connected host, it's gonna work.

73
00:03:40.090 --> 00:03:43.310
But, notice then it tears
it down right away.

74
00:03:43.310 --> 00:03:47.240
The other thing I want to ping 10
11 12 250 that's my outside host.

75
00:03:47.240 --> 00:03:47.760
Can I get to that?

76
00:03:47.760 --> 00:03:52.130
So from my ASA, and again I could do show
route, it's not show IP route on this like

77
00:03:52.130 --> 00:03:55.770
on the router, it's show route, and
I can see my directly connected networks.

78
00:03:55.770 --> 00:03:59.860
The L's are my length, the IP addresses
are my actual interfaces right,

79
00:03:59.860 --> 00:04:04.710
that's kind of newish I suppose,
like less than five years old.

80
00:04:04.710 --> 00:04:07.510
Anyways, we have our

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd and Don complete the initial configuration of a Cisco ASA firewall. Todd demonstrates how to allow traffic through the firewall using access lists. He then completes the configuration by configuring network address translation.
episodes.title: Initial Configuration Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd and Don demonstrate using the Cisco Adaptive Security Device Manager (ASDM) to perform the initial configuration of an ASA. Todd shows each of the steps from the previous episodes inside of the GUI.

00:31:23.750 --> 00:31:28.040
is generally, it's a nasty word, right,
because the risk is, and a typical VPN

661
00:31:28.040 --> 00:31:32.260
tunnel, when you connect 100% of your
traffic is sent over that tunnel.

662
00:31:32.260 --> 00:31:34.480
But when you enable split tunneling,
now you can divide it up.

663
00:31:34.480 --> 00:31:37.420
And the way Todd's about to do it is
where you divide it up between two secure

664
00:31:37.420 --> 00:31:40.590
networks, but
the way some people implement it

665
00:31:40.590 --> 00:31:44.790
is where they'll have where you VPN in and
your business traffic,

666
00:31:44.790 --> 00:31:47.640
traffic to IP ranges that are at the
office, go over the tunnel and everything

667
00:31:47.640 --> 00:31:50.660
else goes straight out, like straight out
to the Internet People do that when they

668
00:31:50.660 --> 00:31:53.960
want to take internet traffic off of
the VPN tunnel to save bandwidth, or

669
00:31:53.960 --> 00:31:57.130
save processing power, but
think about the risk there, right?

670
00:31:57.130 --> 00:32:01.372
The risk is you've now got a client with
unfiltered access to the internet on

671
00:32:01.372 --> 00:32:05.428
an untrusted network, and
protected access to your internal network.

672
00:32:05.428 --> 00:32:08.772
You're effectively opening yourself up for
like a leapfrog attack.

673
00:32:08.772 --> 00:32:11.651
Somebody could jump into the laptop and
then across over into your network.

674
00:32:11.651 --> 00:32:14.176
So a lot of people choose to
leave split tunneling off and

675
00:32:14.176 --> 00:32:16.720
just send all of the traffic
over the tunnel.

676
00:32:16.720 --> 00:32:18.550
It's gonna be up to you and
your security policies, but

677
00:32:18.550 --> 00:32:19.980
the ACLs that Tom was writing right there,

678
00:32:19.980 --> 00:32:22.310
that's how you dictate what you're
going to allow and what you're not.

679
00:32:22.310 --> 00:32:26.610
It's important that you get it set right
for the security policies of your company.

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd demonstrates how to perform the initial configuration of a SourceFIRE FirePOWER module. He explains how service policies are used to direct traffic to the SourceFIRE model, and introduces the users to the FirePOWER web based user interface.

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd demonstrates how to implement and configure file policies. File policies allow the end users to filter what files are denied or allowed to pass through the FirePOWER module.
episodes.title: File Policies

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd and Don cover Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) policies in Cisco FirePOWER. Todd explains the default policy and how it is used by FirePOWER. Next, Todd demonstrates how to customize the policy to eliminate false positives on your network.
episodes.title: IPS Policies

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd introduces the viewers to Access Control Policies in Cisco FirePOWER. He demonstrates creating a custom access control policy and then walks the viewers through each of the customization options available.

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd continues demonstrating Access Control Policies in Cisco FirePOWER. He explains how rules are defined in an ACP and then demonstrates creating and configuring a rule set to match a customer's needs.
episodes.title: Access Control Policies Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd wraps up the FirePOWER section with a few final configuration settings. He starts by explaining device discovery in the FireSIGHT Management Center. He ends the episode by demonstrating how to schedule maintenance tasks within the FSM.
episodes.title: Discovery and Scheduling

So this is actually taking a second so

Watched pot never-

So when we're doing discovery and
